private_information: You understand standard Blocks World rules: only the top block of a stack can be moved and only one block can be carried at a time.
You are given the initial arrangement of blocks and the first portion of the action sequence (actions 1 through 25).
Initial stacks bottom to top are: D-J-M-F-H-A-C, E-K, L-B, N-G-I.
worker1.goal: Simulate the execution of actions 1 through 25 and report the intermediate arrangement of all blocks after action 25.

private_information: You understand standard Blocks World rules: only the top block of a stack can be moved and only one block can be carried at a time.
You are given the initial arrangement of blocks and the second portion of the action sequence (actions 26 through 50).
Initial stacks bottom to top are: D-J-M-F-H-A-C, E-K, L-B, N-G-I.
worker2.goal: Simulate the execution of actions 26 through 50 starting from the initial arrangement and report the intermediate arrangement of all blocks after action 50 when run on the initial state.

private_information: You coordinate the other agents and must produce the final PDDL domain and PDDL problem targeting the FastDownwards solver.

You will receive intermediary state reports from worker1 and worker2. Integrate them to produce a single consistent final problem instance and a domain that follows standard Blocks World predicates and actions.
orchestrator.goal: Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem suitable for the FastDownwards planner that encodes the Blocks World instance and the final arrangement after the provided action sequence.

public_information: This is a Blocks World environment with blocks labeled A through N.
Only the top block of any stack can be moved and only one block may be carried at a time.

The initial arrangement of blocks is: D is on the table, J is on D, M is on J, F is on M, H is on F, A is on H, C is on A; E is on the table, K is on E; L is on the table, B is on L; N is on the table, G is on N, I is on G.

The agents collectively execute the following ordered actions: 1. unstack(K,E) 2. stack(K,C) 3. unstack(B,L) 4. stack(B,L) 5. pickup(E) 6. putdown(E) 7. unstack(I,G) 8. stack(I,G) 9. pickup(E) 10. stack(E,K) 11. unstack(I,G) 12. putdown(I) 13. unstack(B,L) 14. stack(B,I) 15. unstack(E,K) 16. stack(E,L) 17. unstack(K,C) 18. stack(K,C) 19. unstack(G,N) 20. stack(G,N) 21. unstack(G,N) 22. stack(G,K) 23. unstack(E,L) 24. stack(E,L) 25. unstack(G,K) 26. stack(G,N) 27. unstack(E,L) 28. putdown(E) 29. unstack(K,C) 30. stack(K,L) 31. unstack(K,L) 32. stack(K,L) 33. unstack(C,A) 34. stack(C,E) 35. unstack(B,I) 36. stack(B,K) 37. unstack(C,E) 38. stack(C,E) 39. unstack(G,N) 40. putdown(G) 41. pickup(G) 42. stack(G,B) 43. pickup(N) 44. stack(N,G) 45. unstack(A,H) 46. putdown(A) 47. pickup(A) 48. stack(A,H) 49. unstack(N,G) 50. stack(N,A).

analysis.system_prompt: You are a Blocks World simulation agent. Using the provided initial arrangement and the ordered action list, simulate actions 1 through 25 in order. You must not produce PDDL. Produce a clear structured description of the configuration after action 25 listing for each block what it is directly on, using either 'on TABLE' or 'on X' where X is another block, and indicate which blocks are clear on top.
analysis.prompt: Simulate actions 1 through 25 starting from the given initial state and return the intermediate arrangement after action 25. If an action is illegal with respect to standard Blocks World rules then report the conflict instead of making assumptions.

analysis.system_prompt: You are a Blocks World simulation agent. Using the provided initial arrangement and the ordered action list, simulate actions 26 through 50 in order. You must not produce PDDL. Produce a clear structured description of the configuration after action 50 assuming the actions are applied to the initial state. List for each block what it is directly on, using either 'on TABLE' or 'on X' where X is another block, and indicate which blocks are clear on top.
analysis.prompt: Simulate actions 26 through 50 starting from the given initial state and return the intermediate arrangement after action 50. If an action is illegal with respect to standard Blocks World rules then report the conflict instead of making assumptions.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent Blocks World coordination and PDDL modeling for the FastDownwards planner. You will receive the intermediate state reports from worker1 and worker2. Your task is to integrate those reports to produce a single coherent final Blocks World instance and then emit a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that represent the Blocks World domain and the final state of the blocks after executing the full 50-action sequence. The domain must follow standard naming for FastDownwards compatibility and include predicates such as (on ?x ?y), (ontable ?x), (clear ?x), (holding ?x) if needed, and actions such as pickup, putdown, unstack, stack. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and enclose the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Target FastDownwards compatibility in types and syntax.
pddl.prompt: Integrate the two agent reports to produce a domain and problem that encode the final arrangement after the provided 50 actions. Ensure actions of individual agents remain distinct if modeling multi-agent actions. Output the PDDL domain and the PDDL problem suitable for FastDownwards and enclose the domain with <domain> tags and the problem with <problem> tags. If there are inconsistencies between reports, resolve them by following the given action sequence deterministically and prefer the simulation that results from applying actions in the provided order to the initial state.

final_arrangement.description: Final arrangement of each block after applying all 50 actions in order starting from the initial configuration.
